Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: SAM's Contribution to Increased Ocean Heat Content on the Continental Shelf of Western Antarctic Peninsula
Award.AbstractNarration:
The dynamics of a warming Southern Ocean and its interactions with Antarctic continental shelf circulation patterns brought about by the intensification of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, circumpolar winds which prevail between 30 and 60 0 S, remains uncertain in several respects. Current global climate models (e.g. IPCC/AR4) attribute intensification of the westerlies to anthropogenic increases in greenhouse gases in the troposphere along with decreased levels of stratospheric ozone, seasonally observed as the polar ozone hole. Other dynamical oceanic processes may also be involved.

This numerical and analysis project seeks to further evaluate the contribution of oceanic heat content to the accelerating warming and sub-glacial melting currently being observed in the terminal ice streams in the Amundsen and Bellingshausen Seas, and the adjacent rapidly warming Western Antarctic Peninsula (WAP). Use of the Palmer Station LTER data set, which extends back to 1993, provides a observational series which in part covers the time period where changes in atmospheric circulation and air temperatures are most likely to have taken place. Use of a regional oceanic numerical model (3-D, fully dynamic) under contrasting wind regimes corresponding to observed (more positive) trends in the Southern Annular Mode will shed light on the dynamics of climate change in these sensitive continental shelf regions of the continent.

The impact of melting glaciers and ice sheets on global sea level rise is an acknowledged area of uncertainty in the most recent IPCC assessment, and would be a direct impact of climate change on society in this century.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The near-shore ocean on the continental shelf west of the Antarctic Peninsula (wAP)  is warming  faster than other regions around Antarctica. This warming is due to processes in both the atmosphere and the ocean. For example,  water movement and temperature on the continental shelf responds to  hanges in wind speed and direction. Understanding temperature changes in the coastal ocean is crucial for predicting the rate of ice loss from Antarctica,
and therefore global sea level rise. One specific question that needs to be
answered is how warm  water is able to move from the deep ocean onto the shelf providing heat to melt floating ice shelves and glaciers.


Due to the remote and inhospitable nature of Antarctica, there are few ocean observations in the region. Therefore, we are using numerical ocean models to help improve our understanding of ocean variability, as well as interactions with the floating ice or atmosphere. Two different ocean models have been developed, with different grid spacing: 4 km and 1.5 km. The 4 km model is an upgrade of a previously model (also with 4 km grid spacing) in which the bottom topography and the thickness of floating glacial ice sheets has been improved based on recent measurements. In particular, a glacially created
trough (Belgica Trough) in the southern part of the wAP is much better represented. 

Previous studies have shown that small-scale swirls and narrow currents are important for transporting heat towards the coast; features that cannot be fully resolved on a 4 km grid. A separate model has been set up with a grid  pacing of 1.5 km to better represent these small features.  Most large-scale climate models have grid spacing much larger than 4 km. Understanding the difference between our two simulations may then help to improve large-scale simulations, and therefore our understanding of the how the Antarctic environment will change in the future.

Both of these models were forced by fine scale atmospheric conditions (grid spacing of  15 to 20 km). This relatively fine atmospheric grid represents the flow modification due to rugged coastal mountain ranges which drive low level winds along the coast; such features are not well represented in coarser atmospheric analyses or global climate models. Our simulations cover a seven year period from 2006 to 2012, revealing how the ocean properties change from year to year.

Simulations from both models have been compared to observations from the region. These come from instruments lowered from ships, as well as  instruments attached to seals. The seal-based observations are available in late fall and early winter, when sea ice prevents ships from sampling the  southern half of the wAP. Additional observations come from moored sensors and from underneath the George VI ice shelf. 

Model results clearly show that the finer grid spacing allows stronger transport of the warm deep water onto the shelf, creating near bottom temperature in the 1.5 km model in better agreement with these observations
than the 4 km model. These results will help to improve our understanding of heat transport towards ice shelves, and therefore melt rates in the region.  Both meltwater and warm deep water also provide vital nutrients to ecosystems living in the coastal waters.
